docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: ON THE CREST OF A HILL IN Altura, Minn., where the air is so clear the eye can fasten easily on the emerald ridges of Sugar Loaf Bluff miles to the west and the Mississippi River valley to the east, the century's third wave of farm technology has arrived in the form of a glass vial in John Kurtz's milking barn.
docs.snippet: LEAD: ON THE CREST OF A HILL IN Altura, Minn., where the air is so clear the eye can fasten easily on the emerald ridges of Sugar Loaf Bluff miles to the west and the Mississippi River valley to the east, the century's third wave of farm technology...

byline.original: By Keith Schneider; Keith Schneider reports on agriculture for The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: THREE steps up a stoop to the door, a brick front and three windows looking out on the street. Inside, four or more rooms; outside, a backyard for plants, socializing and enjoying the breeze. A typical Camden row house. According to experts, these small and inexpensive individual dwellings once counted among the best ordinary urban housing in America.

headline.main: A Once Vital, Cohesive Community Is Slowly, but Not Inevitably, Dying

docs.snippet: LEAD: THREE steps up a stoop to the door, a brick front and three windows looking out on the street. Inside, four or more rooms; outside, a backyard for plants, socializing and enjoying the breeze. A typical Camden row house.  According to experts,...

byline.original: By CAMILO JOSE VERGARA; Camilo Jose Vergara, a staff associate at the Center for the Social Sciences at Columbia University, prowled slums for five years to create the photographic exhibition ''Ruins and Revivals: The Architecture of Urban Devastation.'' For more than five years, he has been working on a book on the subject

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Federal agricultural scientists are secretly growing coca, the plant from which cocaine is derived, in a Government complex near here as part of an intensive effort to find an effective means of eradicating the crop abroad.

headline.main: U.S. Secretly Grows Coca to Find Way to Destroy Cocaine's Source

docs.snippet: LEAD: Federal agricultural scientists are secretly growing coca, the plant from which cocaine is derived, in a Government complex near here as part of an intensive effort to find an effective means of eradicating the crop abroad.

byline.original: By CLIFFORD D. MAY, Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Surgeons removed a malignant tumor today from the stomach of President Jose Napoleon Duarte of El Salvador, but left his cancerous liver untouched. Medical experts said the move indicated that he had little chance of long-term survival.

headline.main: Salvadoran Leader Has Surgery; Outlook Is Grim

docs.snippet: LEAD: Surgeons removed a malignant tumor today from the stomach of President Jose Napoleon Duarte of El Salvador, but left his cancerous liver untouched. Medical experts said the move indicated that he had little chance of long-term survival.

byline.original: By WARREN E. LEARY, Special to the New York Times
